production.title: Production
production.content: {{country}}’s total domestic plastic production was estimated between 14 to 19.3 million tonnes, worth over USD 70 billion. Polymer production includes LDPE, LLDPE, HDPE, PP, PS, PVC, PET, ABS, ASA, SAN, PUR, marine coatings, fibres, road marking coatings, elastomers (tyres), bioplastics and others.

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: {{country}} is a full-spectrum plastics economy, with large activity across polymers, intermediates, and finished goods.
Imports of primary plastics nearly doubled to USD 18.6 billion between 2017 and 2022, driven by heavy reliance on polyethylene, PVC, and other resins, despite significant domestic production.
Trade balances reflect rising upstream pressure. Net plastic imports widened sharply from USD 2.3 billion in 2020 to USD 11 billion in 2022, while exports of base polymers remain limited.

{{country}}’s trade profile shows strong downstream plastic manufacturing capacity, converting imported and domestically produced polymers into higher-value products, such as sheets, films, packaging, synthetic yarns, textiles, apparel, and construction materials, while exporting more finished goods than it imports.

Textile exports are a cornerstone of the plastic economy, with the top 20 textile, apparel, and footwear exports totaling around USD 23 billion (~5% of total exports), roughly double the value of related imports.
Asia supplies over 70% of {{country}}’s plastic imports, mainly primary forms, while exports are globally diversified with strong surpluses to Africa and the Americas.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 128,729 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 29,173 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 64% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 15% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 7% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 14% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

The plastic imports included estimated 4,084 million USD of plastic packaging imports with notoriously short product lifetime.

Plastic exports

A total of 96,361 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 18,143 million, of which:

  • ~ 21% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 19% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 16% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 45% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports included estimated 2,721 million USD of plastic packaging.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2022, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 64.6%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has increased by 29.1%.

{{country}}’s imports of primary plastics rose from USD 10,936 million to USD 18,639 million between 2017 and 2022. Exports of primary plastics are also large at USD 3,745 million in 2022. {{country}} also trades heavily in intermediates in both directions. Imports of intermediate forms doubled from USD 2,050 million to USD 4,323 million between 2017 and 2022, with exports of intermediate forms at a similar scale of USD 3,423 million in 2022. {{country}} also exports more intermediate goods than it imports.

Exports of final plastic products have grown from USD 6,132 million to USD 8,118 million between 2017 and 2022, while imports of final goods have increased more modestly, from USD 3,061 million to USD 3,997 million (particularly since 2020).

{{country}} imports more plastic waste than it exports. Imports fell sharply after 2019, consistent with tightening controls on waste imports, but have fluctuated post-2020.
trade.tradingPartners: Asia is {{country}}’s dominant trading partner, importing USD 23,267 million in 2022, accounting for more than 70% of {{country}}’s total plastic imports. Europe ranks second at USD 3,960 million, followed by the Americas at USD 1,895 million. Exports are much more geographically diverse, running trade surpluses with Africa and the Americas.
trade.productCategories: WTO HS-level trade data indicate that {{country}}’s plastic trade is significantly larger than suggested by UNCTAD data, which captures a narrower set of plastic-related HS categories. Imports are predominantly plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39), dominated by primary polymers and industrial resins, including polyethylene (USD 4.6 billion), PVC (USD 3.6 billion), and other resins and polyesters (USD 2.5 billion). This reflects a structural shortfall in domestic upstream polymer capacity relative to manufacturing demand. {{country}}, therefore, relies heavily on imported virgin resins and speciality polymers to supply domestic converters. While some primary polymers are exported, their share is small. Exports are more concentrated in processed materials and finished goods, dominated by textiles, apparel, and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), including apparel, footwear, bags, and home textiles (approximately USD 23 billion across top 20 categories, 5% of total exports). This is followed by plastic sheets, films, and packaging under the category of plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39). New rubber tyres are the main exported product under the rubber (HS Chapter 40) category.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
High domestic production, coupled with net imports of plastics, indicates that {{country}} consumes significant quantities of both imported and domestically produced plastics.

In 2019, plastic consumption in {{country}} (21.01 kg/capita or 29.33 million tonnes) was predominantly packaging (25%), textiles (17%), and buildings and construction (14%). Other prominent applications include transportation (14%, excluding tyres), consumer and institutional products (10%), and electrical/electronics (4%).

The import surge from USD 2.3 billion to USD 11.0 billion between 2020 and 2022 in the UNCTAD data is reflected by significant increases in the WTO database, particularly for ethylene polymers, PVC and halogenated polymers, and propylene and olefin polymers in primary form.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: {{country}} generates around 192 million tonnes of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) annually.
Collection efficiency is highly uneven: major cities collect up to 95% of waste, whereas smaller cities often collect less than half, resulting in environmental leakage.
{{country}} produces an estimated 15–19 million tonnes of plastic waste each year, making it one of the world’s largest plastic waste generators.
By material, fibres and polyolefins dominate plastic waste composition. By source, packaging dominates, followed by textiles.

Formal plastic recycling remains limited at around 13% (~2 million tonnes/year), while the informal sector plays a dominant but poorly quantified role, potentially lifting total recycling and reuse to 39%.
Despite high recyclability of plastic waste stream, around 46% is mismanaged, with large volumes sent to landfills, incinerated, co-processed in cement kilns or openly burned.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 192,000 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020. A study on global waste management modeling showed 82% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, while another study estimated waste collection coverage ranges from 70–95% in major cities but can drop below 50% in smaller cities.

The global waste management modelling showed that annual plastic emission, including both debris and open burning, is 9,275,777 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 7 kg/person/year. This is largely due to the uncontrolled management of disposal facilities. An estimated percentage of municipal solid waste managed in controlled facilities is 14.7%. The estimated proportion of the plastic waste generated that is being recycled was 13% (2.4 million tonnes) in 2019. This is a significant increase from 0.2 million tonnes recycled in 2000.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.38 kg per person per day. Estimates of per capita municipal solid waste generation range from 0.19 to 0.99 kg per day, depending on population size and associated tourism, with an average of 0.39 kg.

Data from selected city case studies provide further insights. Primary data collection through a waste composition survey recorded that the share of plastic waste within the collected waste was 17% in Mangalore in 2021, and 18% in Thiruvananthapuram in 2021.

Models by the OECD and Plasteax estimated total plastic waste generation at 15.3–18.5 million tonnes in 2019–2021, an approximate 5-fold increase since 2000 (~3.5 million tonnes). Plastic waste generation is primarily from packaging (5.5–7.4 million tonnes or >40%) and textiles (3.8–4.1 million tonnes), with the most dominant materials being polypropylene (3.1–4.2 million tonnes) and polyester (3.9 million tonnes).

Models also estimate that 13% of plastic waste is recycled, while 46% is mismanaged (8.5 million tonnes), 36% landfilled (6.7 million tonnes), 4% incinerated (0.7 million tonnes), and 0.5% littered (0.1 million tonnes).

A 2022 World Economic Forum study in Maharashtra found that plastic waste in municipal solid waste consists primarily of flexible mono-material plastics (40%), followed by rigid mono-material plastics (18%), plastic bottles (17%), multilayer materials (16%), and household goods (9%).
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

There is no data on plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste in {{country}}.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Plastic leakage to the environment was estimated as ~2.2 million tonnes in 2019, dominated by macroplastics (~88%) from mismanaged waste (~94%).
Plastics dominate {{country}}n beach litter, accounting for 65–85% of all debris, with single-use packaging made mainly from PE and PP as some of the most common items.
Marine litter composition clearly points to household consumption, tourism, and fishing activities as some of the main sources.
Estuarine surveys show high prevalence of HDPE, PVC, PP, and PS, highlighting rivers and creeks as critical leakage pathways.
Microplastics are already widespread on {{country}}n beaches, with up to 42% of particles in the 1–5 mm range, dominated by secondary fragments.
environment.content:
Beach litter

Plastic has consistently been identified as the most dominant litter type on {{country}}n beaches, accounting for between 65% and 85% in between 2018–2021 across various beaches, with Single Use Plastics (SUPs) being predominant among items found. PE and PP have also been identified as some of the most dominant polymer types.

One study found litter abundance to be higher during monsoon (1.10 ± 0.39 items/m²) than post-monsoon (0.86 ± 0.32 items/m²).

In 2012, a study on microplastics on beaches in Mumbai reported small plastic particles (1–20mm) to dominate beach litter, with 42% being microplastics (1–5mm). The microplastic was shown to primarily consist of secondary fragments, although primary pellets did account for 17% by number.

Common plastic items in the environment

The distribution and typology of marine litter have been found to be representative of household, tourism, and fishing sources.

A recent assessment of an estuary in Navi Mumbai recorded a high prevalence of HDPE, as well as PVC, PP, and PS along the Panvel creek.

lifeCycleInsights.title: Life Cycle Insights
keyTrends: {{country}} is a full-spectrum plastics economy, from polymers to finished goods. {{country}} produces 14–19.3 million tonnes of plastics annually, worth USD 70 billion.
Textiles and apparel form one of the largest plastic-intensive export sectors. {{country}} exports ~USD 23 billion in textile/apparel/footwear — nearly double the import value.

{{country}} consumed ~29 million tonnes of plastic in 2019 (21 kg/capita). Plastic use is embedded across {{country}}’s economy; textiles and packaging together make up over 40% of national plastic consumption.
{{country}} generates 15–19 million tonnes of plastic waste annually; only 13% is formally recycled and 46% is mismanaged through landfilling, open burning, or leakage.
An estimated plastic leakage from municipal solid waste management system in {{country}} is 9.2 million tonnes per year (7 kg/person/year), including both debris and open burning.
lifeCycleInsights.content:
{{country}} is a full-spectrum plastics economy, from polymers to finished goods. Production covers the entire polymer spectrum: LDPE, HDPE, PP, PVC, PET, synthetic fibres, elastomers, bioplastics, and more. {{country}} has a mature plastics industry but still faces significant gaps in high-quality resin capacity, resulting in continued dependence on imports of virgin polymers which nearly doubled to USD 18.6 billion (2017–2022).

Textiles and apparel form one of the largest plastic-intensive export sectors. These sectors depend heavily on synthetic fibres (PET/polyester, nylon, PP). Major exports: women’s garments, T-shirts, linen, footwear. Major inputs: synthetic yarns, knitted fabrics, resins.

{{country}} consumes large volumes of plastic across multiple sectors. Plastic use is embedded across {{country}}’s economy; textiles and packaging together make up over 40% of national plastic consumption.

{{country}} generates massive plastic waste, with nearly half mismanaged. Only 13% is formally recycled and 46% is mismanaged. Estimates based on waste data suggest that {{country}} generates 33.5 million tonnes of plastic waste from municipal solid waste, with only 14.7% managed in controlled facilities.

Significant plastic leakage affects rivers, coasts, and marine ecosystems. Plastic has been identified as the most dominant litter type on {{country}}n beaches, accounting for between 65% and 85% (2018–2021), with Single Use Plastics being predominant.
